bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Richard M. Hewitt and the Committee on Medical Education and Research, June 20, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses the ethics of having his yellow fever talk reprinted and distributed by the Wyeth Company. A note by Hewitt on the second page states that he sees no ethical problems with publication.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Richard M. Hewitt and the Committee on Medical Education and Research, June 20, 1941

opener.salute: To Dr. Hewitt and the Committee on Medical Education and Research:

div1.p:
You will remember that in connection with my researches on the
history of the conquest of yellow fever, I was called upon to advise Mr.
Dean Cornwell, the New York painter, regarding the details of the conquest.
As a result, I was invited to give the dedicatory address at the unveiling
of this painting in Cleveland during the A.M.A. week. The affair was a very
nice one and entirely ethical. The invited group was small but very select.
It included the mayor of Cleveland, Dr. Van Etten, the President of the A.M.A.,
Dr. Lahey, the President-elect of the A.M.A. (see enclosed photograph), Miss
Blossom Reed, Walter Reed's daughter, Mr. Kissinger, one of the survivors of
the experiment, representatives from a few medical schools, among them the
University of Virginia, and Dean Eben Carey, of Milwaukee (who, by the way,
has invited me to give the same talk in Milwaukee this Fall), and representatives
from a few art museums, also former Surgeon. General Ireland & wife, Col, Siler etc.

The Wyeth Company which sponsors these paintings, pays about $10,000
a piece for them. In addition, I know they have spent several thousand dollars
having Mr. Cornwell and their representatives visit Cuba and other places to get
the proper background for the painting. When these paintings are finished, they
are sent to various medical exhibits (commercial) and are also sent to various
medical schools and medical societies which request them. Thereafter they are
deposited on permanent loan in some appropriate place. For example, the Osler
painting is now in the old Blockley Hospital, Philadelphia. The Walter Reed
painting may be deposited either at the University of Virginia or the Walter Reed
Hospital.

Meanwhile, colored plates are made of the painting and as a type of
ethical advertisement, the Wyeth Co. send out about 15,000 of these, already framed
and autographed by the artist; one of mine doesn't even have the name of John Wyeth
Co. on it--the other one does. In addition, as many as 100,000 copies are sent
to various physicians throughout the country, these being unframed and not signed
by the artist. With each of the previous paintings, they have sent a small brochure
giving a brief synopsis of the subject painted. A well known Chicago physiologist
(not Carlson, and at the moment I can't remember his name but he has been here fre-
quently) was the chief advisor on the Beaumont painting. The Wyeth people were
already preparing this brochure but when they heard my talk, Mr. Law, the President,
and Mr. Kellogg, the head of their promotion department, said that they would very
much like to discard their own write-up and send with each copy of the picture a
copy of my talk. In order to avoid any possible criticism, they suggested that I
have my talk published somewhere, if possible in a medical journal and they would buy
the appropriate large number of reprints. The other alternative would be to obtain
permission to print my talk illustrated with a copy of their painting.

Walter Simpson of Dayton, Ohio, was in the audience. Unbeknown to me,
he showed a copy of my talk to Paul Hoeber, who said he would like to publish it
in the Annals of Medical History. That evening he discussed it with Fishbein who
said he would like to have a shortened version of it for Hygeia. From the standpoint
of the company, they would of course like to have included the first two pages where
I call attention to the painstaking accuracy of the artist. I suspect that neither
Fishbein nor Hoeber would include the first two pages but would probably start
on the bottom of page 2. The Wyeth folks suggested that Minnesota Medicine
might publish it and they would be glad to give this journal the color plates
or colored reproduction already for insertion at no cost to them, and the only
mention of the Wyeth people would be the small name “Wyeth” printed at the lower
right hand corner of the reproduction. Time Magazine has already reproduced
their Beaumont painting and a colored reproduction of the Beaumont painting has
been used as a frontispiece of the Mosby reprint of the Life of Beaumont.

What would you advise me to do? Since my talk has nothing to do with
pills or medicine but is merely a few words of well-merited praise for the artist
and then a short version of the yellow fever story, it seems to me it is entirely
ethical for me to let them use it some way or other. It seems to me that this
is analgous to the use of certain articles by Banting, Sir Henry Dale Minister and others
in the Eli Lilly Souvenir Volume which I am sending for your attention. The
only ulterior motive I have in letting them use it is that I have included one
brief paragraph on Camp Lazear, as we have found it recently. I am careful not
to ask for help in my attempts to raise some money to memorialize this camp site
properly but I can well imagine that if a copy of my talk went out to many thousand
physicians, at least a few might spontaneously be stimulated to join in with me
in my campaign to preserve the camp site and the little historical building which
still remains and which I purchased this Spring in Cuba.

The easiest solution would be of course just to let the Wyeth folks
print my talk as is with the introduction unchanged or slightly changed. But I
will abide by the decision of yourself and the Committee on Medical Education
and Research.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench 6-20-41
Recommendation 1: Whether Dr. Hench desires to send this to a
journal or to let Wyeth be the original publisher, it seems to me an ethical
project. It puffs no remedy and Dr. Hench, with his present position among
those interested in the history of yellow fever was the obvious one to give
the address.
Richard M. Hewitt
